Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: How to make great graphs with a clear message, what to pay attention when making a graph, message box, color-blind issues, story maps, Tableau, etc.
Design principles and skills.
Not much to be honest, I sort of checked out of the class when I wasn't getting much out of it.
Nothing much.
None.
Data visualization skills applicable to the real-world setting
Data viz - Tableau, Excel, GIS Story Maps, how to use color/data/visual design to create effective graphics to communicate health (and environmental) information to different audiences
Learned how to use ggplot and Story Maps and a good overview on the principles and tools of data visualization.
A better understanding of what a good visualization looks like and the different ways that data can be visualized. A bit more practice with R. An introduction to Tableau and more work with Story Maps

I have done a lot of data visualization work, so this course was an interesting formalization of my skills and understandings before. I learned a lot about visualization best practices and "rules," as well as how to use Tableau. When I look at a graphic that *isn't* well designed, I now have a better idea of why it doesn't look good; before I likely would have been able to tell that something was off but wouldn't have known what.
The skills that we gained were good, for example, learning how to use Tableau. But we wasted a lot of time in RStudio.
Science communication and data visualization best practices, as well as some technical knowledge in R (ggplot package).
Data visualization

Tableau
More design work with Excel
StoryMaps skill

I learned about how data visualization isn't just artistic, but rather there are important rules to follow to enhance clarity for the viewer. it was great to see so many different kinds of data and how tailored the presentation of the data should be to the message being conveyed.
I learned both practical skills for doing data visualization and also the theoretical basis of principles used to most effectively communicate data.
Principles and tools for data visualization.
Tableau, a little bit of R, excel graph making, best practices in data visualization.
I learned R and Tableau, both of which are extremely useful. Also learned the principles of visualization and how to construct to a visual narrative.
Key visual design principles
Principles of effective design for science communication, how to manipulate the appearance of plots/graphs in R and Tableau
Learned the basics to new programs for data visualization (R and Tableau) and gained some new skills in data organization within Excel.
The class spent time learning about different ways to visualize data and different types of software to use for that visualization.
The course was primarily focused on design principles and how they can be used to make data figures that are easily accessible to different audiences.
Learned how to make compelling, concise, and meaningful graphics in a variety of data visualization programs.
Breaking down data visualization into its simplest parts to build readable graphs and tables.
Data visualization, design concepts
I learned a lot about the theory and thought processes that help to make an effective and communicative graphic.
Learnt where/how to go about teaching myself R
I learned how to use R, Tableau, and basic design skills.

I audited this course because I was interested in an introduction to data visualization specifically with R. At the beginning of the semester, the problem sets allowed me to develop this skill. After we stopped using R, my engagement with the class decreased.

Not quite aligned. I was expecting a scientific graph design class but this one is more like a journalism/communication-based class. However, the basic rules of graphic design are reviewed and summarized, which are indeed useful.
Good.
Not at all.
Not all.
I expected to learn R in this course, and that did not happen.
Perfectly!
Useful knowledge but more theory-based than applied.

I expected to get a little more practical work with data visualization in ways that were more hands-on and learning through doing, when I feel like in reality I was not guided too much in that work but expected to try and work through it on my own some in homework. While this was a factor of the class size being large, I think this would be important to note for the future.

I think this class shifted a lot over the semester--I had been excited to build up my R skills a bit more. R was actually one of the reasons I took the class... I learned a lot but it definitely wasn't what I expected. (I think that's true of everyone, including the professors!)
The class did not meet all my expectations.

It deviated slightly from my expectations. I thought that I would get a more robust technical knowledge of R through this course. However, this course turned out to be more focused on science communication, with the R component almost being optional. Little guidance was given to us on these technical aspects, and the professors chose to focus instead on more of the methods of science communication.
Fairly aligned
It was about what I expected, though I hadn't anticipated the refinement of the visuals to take as long as it did.
They aligned well with my expectations.
Great, they totally met my expectation.
I expected to learn R in a bit more depth. I also enjoyed learning Tableau but felt as though I had to learn most things on my own regarding that.
Well
Design principles met expectations. However, I thought I'd become better at R. Turns out it's hard to teach yourself R during a semester.
It fell short of my expectations. I was hoping to have more consistent instruction/tutorials from the class to get more familiar with R that I was ultimately able to through this course.
I was hoping to spend a little more time talking about when to use different software.

I signed up for this course hoping to develop my programming skills from a data visualization perspective. I think I may have misinterpreted this class as a "Data Visualization in R" course. It seems the majority of students did not want the R content in the course, so the final content of the course ended up being too basic and hence disappointing. I tried to incorporate R as much as possible even after the R content was removed following the midterm evaluations. However, since it was no longer the focus of the course, there were less materials (i.e. example scripts) provided to develop these skills, so I often ended up working on the weekly assignments in Excel, which I was already very familiar with. I did really enjoy the Healy chapters and the accompanying exercises. One suggestion is to have more options available for the weekly assignments given the large differences in background. I appreciated the weeks when Healy chapters were available as an assignment option, but I also think it would be useful to have the option of workshopping a figure from your own work that could ultimately feed into the final project.
Expected further instruction on using data visualization software, but theoretical instruction was on par with expectations.
Well
I wished the course focused more on the design aspects than the data analysis aspects.
Low - although initially appearing focused, the course quickly became to broad and development of particular skill sets became diluted and less valuable.

Strength: interesting makeover assignments, good use of piazza, clear feedback from instructors, great guest lecturers.
Weakness: lectures are dry, assignments are posted either too late or too early (mostly on Tuesday instead of Monday, and once assigned Saturday and due Monday), sometimes chaotic illustrations (there are sometimes contradictory pdf and docx documents, and little guidance on draft #1), neglect the needs of students who know how to code and want to learn more.
I think the course should have a requirement that students know R, so we cover more advanced material and focus on data visualization instead of learning R.
The course didnt give hands on experience on any tool. There wasnt any need of guest lecturers.
This class was meant to be smaller and involve a lab to teach R. Instead, the class was too large, contained no lab and had lectures that failed to teach new skills.

I wish the assignments would have been posted earlier - at times, there were only a few days between when the assignment was posted and when it was due and I was unable to devote as much time to the assignment as I would have liked. The short turnaround time discouraged thoughtful responses. A due date over the weekend was also not ideal. 

I also wish the final project assignment would have remained consistent. When the project requirements changed halfway through, I felt the work I had done to comply with the old requirements would no longer be recognized.

Overall, I learned a lot in the course and appreciated the chance to develop my visualization skills.

Loved the interactive format - this is how I and a lot of my peers learn best is by doing hands on exercises and diving right in. The class size was large, but through group work and talking with other students, I don't think this significantly took anything away from the course.

Make-Up Mondays were a useful class exercise to apply some of the principles we learned in class. However, instead of addressing a few examples with the whole class, having small group feedback would be more useful with the professors listening in and providing extra commentary. The guest lecturers, particularly David Roberts, was also a fascinating talk into journalism and data visualization.

The strengths were the final project - I enjoyed making a visualization based on a data set, although I think refining what you are all looking for in terms of this final project would be helpful. I also think capping the class to 16 would help provide more hands-on and teaching lessons regarding R or other data visualization techniques would be great. I think the presentations were pretty basic and did not feel very helpful to how I could actually learn to be better at data visualization. I think more group work in class on these types of visualizations would be the most beneficial. I think the guest lecturers were interesting but not always the most applicable to us necessarily and perhaps all of them were not the best use of our class time

The online R textbook and the Williams book are both great! The guest speakers often gave us introductions to the data viz principles we'd already focused on and often didn't really add much to the conversation. Either get rid of/reduce the number of guest speakers or give them more information about what we've covered before they arrive. (Also, don't make us buy books for speakers who are only in class for 1 day.) I liked Jenn and Simon's lectures but felt like we could have covered more ground or gone into more depth by the end of the semester.
Weaknesses are that Simon was not an engaging professor. The strengths are the makeovers and project.

The guest speakers were excellent, and each of them added value to my experience and showed me many positive examples from professionals in the field. I think that the expectations for the final project could have been more structured to facilitate student learning.
Include more interesting content in the lectures

The course should have a clear focus - for example, mastering Tableau. That way, over the semester, students will learn how to use a specific software. Each class should involve a lab workshop, where students could follow along and build new skills.

I could certainly tell it was a new course because the class structure varied a lot. The guest speakers were very useful and interesting. There could have been more support for students to learn the program or technical skills involved. In Renewable Energy Project Finance, there were regular sessions, maybe once every other week, where TAs walked students through a tutorial on the computer, trying to teach a new skill. This might require a larger TA team, but it could be useful to have something similar for this class.

I think the strengths of the course were in it's applied value. I will be using many of the principles I learned in the class for years to come in my own work. I think a weakness was in the organization of the class. It wasn't always clear when/how assignments were supposed to be done.

Strengths: We had phenomenal speakers and it was fun to be able to explore our own dataset for the final project. Also, Jenn and Simon were ALWAYS willing to go above and beyond to help - which is truly appreciated. 
Weaknesses: The class moved a bit too slow at times and didn't feel like it had too much direction/continuity at times. The point allocation for Makeover Mondays felt a bit arbitrary, and also a bit repetitive at times (although it is a good skill to have to train ourselves to think about how to improve graphs). I wish the R segment wasn't scrapped, because I was looking forward to learning that.

-The discussions in class about makeovers were useful. It would be helpful to analyze more bad graphics or good graphics. 
-Message Box never really made sense to me, and I read the PDF. The difference between some of the categories never quite became clear. I did appreciate that there was instruction on how to construct a narrative. 
-The class should be taught like a GIS class- short lecture and then a lab session where we all work on a software tutorial in class. One 30-minute Tableau or Excel tutorial is not enough. I pretty much just had to teach myself the software which was very difficult and time-consuming. The class needs to be a lot smaller for this to work, however.
The changes to the course that the professors made part-way through were excellent and significantly improved the experience.
Most of the lectures, and guest lectures, were interesting and added value. A few of the lectures, however, didn't really add a whole lot to the class, such as the one on Excel.

Strengths: I liked the ability to pursue our own final project topic, and the freedom/flexibility around this assignment. 

Weaknesses: the class felt very disorganized. Many of the lectures felt unnecessary and repetitive of one another (especially from some of the guest lecturers). Some of the lectures additionally felt out of order (e.g. an "Excel 101" halfway through the course, when this would have been much more helpful in the first weeks of class). Homework assignment expectations were often either too high (8+ hours to complete for students unfamiliar with R) or too low (e.g. felt like "busy work" that took less than 30 minutes to complete).

The course spent quite a bit of time discussing things that you should do when creating a graphic but didn't spend enough time describing the tools introduced in the class and when to use them. It would have been nice after each topic if the Professor had spent a moment describing the limiting factors of a given tool, when to use it, and the expected product that you would be able to get out of it.

This course would greatly benefit from a reduction in size and the addition of a lab requirement, wherein students have a chance to practice and develop technical skills before doing the homework. This class should have max 20-25 students in it, and each student should be required to meet with the teaching team at least twice a semester. Tableau is incredibly useful but at times this class felt more self-taught, i.e. attendance at lecture wasn't necessary. By incorporating a lab section, faculty will be able to delve more deeply into the software and students will benefit more.

The course was very well-organized, but as I mentioned above, the main weakness for me was the shift in focus from R to Excel. Perhaps it could be a follow up course to Intro R to ensure that the students have an appropriate level of background to learn the programming language? The weekly assignments were also a weakness as I wished there had been more flexibility in working on independent projects in lieu of the provided makeover. 

I did really enjoy the guest speakers.
Class time could be used more wisely - time should be spent in a more interactive way, not a lecture format.

Strengths: final project, guest speakers, focus on Gestalt principles
Weaknesses: homework instruction
Really glad to have taken the course, though would have preferred additional R tutorials. Wish that aspect wasn't dropped.

The course is geared to so many different people, that I think it didn't fully help any one of those groups.  I think defining the target subjects you want to have in this course and tailoring the course to that group would be helpful.

Strength - its good intentioned and seeks to engage interdisciplinary community in sharing insights and promoting valuable work more publicly
Weaknesses - too broad, not taught by specialists but rather from generalist experience, wasnt challenging enough

The strength is the project-based approach (weekly assignments). A definite weakness was the size of the class and content of the lectures. I think that the portion of lectures designed to teach design principles should be less theoretical. Looking at various examples with a smaller group and discussing issues might have been more effective.
Dont expect that you will learn some tool.

This course is an excellent way to gain exposure to a wide range of data viz tools, best practices, and "real world" work through guest speakers (Nat Geo, NYT, etc), and it is well worth your time! You get what you put into it, and these are all great tools and skills to have for any field (e.g. public health, business, environmental)
I think you would get the most out of this if you already had some practical experience with R and had some data that you were already working with or would be able to work with.
Read the syllabus and shop it--this class has potential! It was first taught in spring 2019 and evolved pretty much constantly all year. It could be great--check it out!
Take this class if you already know how to use Rstudio or if you're working on a dataset.

Start thinking about and working on your final project early in the semester. You'll get a lot more out of the course and you can tailor your skills building to what would be useful to your project. This is also an excellent class to dovetail with another major project that involves a lot of data visualization.
Spend time on assignments
Make sure you either have some experience in R or you are willing to spend long hours learning it.

I would advise students to challenge themselves as much as possible, take advantage of the fact that we have world-renowned journalists sharing best practices, and always go to Jenn/Simon if you have help because they will be more than willing to help you.

You get out what you put into this class. You can learn some interesting and basic tricks and design principles that will be helpful for non-researchers with modest amount of work, or you can really deepen your skills if you invest significantly. Either way, I would recommend this class.

Because this was the first year this class is offered, I'm interested to see how it changes next year. It's promising! I really would have gotten so much more out of the class if I had known R in advance. I really appreciate the effort to include non-coders like me, but felt that it was hard to get much out of the class in the R department without previous expertise with coding.

I recognize that this was the first year this course was offered, and the professors were both very receptive to mid-semester feedback from the class. Regardless of my sub-par experience in this class, I think it has potential to offer students with important skillsets, so I would suggest that someone interested in the topic should shop the class and decide for themselves. Having some familiarity with R would be helpful.
develop a relationship w the professor early
Think about your final project early, so you can have a meaningful and useful product by the end of the class.
Helpful to have background in programs such as R
Take it, but note that you won't learn R in this course, if that is a purpose.
If you want an overview of how to work with data and make simple graphics, it could be a good course.
Dont take this class unless you just want some polishing of your visualizations - not much learnt for the time invested on the homework/ project
